Happiness is the utility in this theory, and the key goal for leaders is to promote policies that contribute to “the greatest happiness of the greatest number.”76

功利主义将所有公民视为平等，也就是说，任何个人的欲望都不会凌驾于他人之上。约翰·斯图亚特·密尔是个例外，因为他主张优先考虑智力上的愉悦而非物质上的享受。非常重要的是，政治自由主义的核心——极端个人主义——在功利主义中并不存在。相反，人们从一开始就被视为社会人，集体的“普遍福祉”是政治领导人的主要关注点。鉴于功利主义者反对自由主义对个人主义的强调，他们反对自由主义的自然权利观念也就不足为奇了。边沁对不可剥夺权利的彻底敌视导致了功利主义的衰落。他批评了美国的《独立宣言》和法国的《人权和公民权宣言》。78

Utilitarianism treats all citizens as equals in the sense that no individual’s desires are favored over another’s. John Stuart Mill is something of an exception, as he argues for privileging intellectual over physical pleasures. Very importantly, the stark individualism central to political liberalism is absent from utilitarianism. People are instead treated as social beings from the start, and the “general well-being” of the collectivity is political leaders’ main concern.77 Given that utilitarians reject the liberal emphasis on individualism, it is not surprising they also reject the liberal conception of natural rights. Bentham’s downright hostility toward inalienable rights led him to criticize both the American Declaration of Independence and the French Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen.78

这并非意味着功利主义者不重视权利，因为权利确实重要。但权利是由政府决定的，并非自然权利。此外，权利的首要目的是促进公共福祉，而非赋予个人追求自身利益的最大自由。换言之，权利对于最大化集体效用至关重要，而非因为个人自由本身就是一种善。这意味着个人权利不仅由国家赋予，而且当其不再服务于公共利益时，国家也可以对其进行限制。这与政治自由主义者对权利的看法截然不同。

None of this is to say rights do not matter for utilitarians, because they do. But they are determined by the government; they are not natural rights. Furthermore, the primary purpose of rights is to promote the general welfare, not to give individuals maximum freedom to pursue their own interests. In other words, rights are important for maximizing collective utility, not because individual freedom is a good in itself. This means not only that individual rights are doled out by the state but also that they can be circumscribed when they no longer serve the common good. This is a far cry from how political liberals think about rights.

在功利主义理论中，领导者扮演着至关重要的角色，因为他们主要负责评估其支持者的愿望，然后与群体和个人达成协议，以最大化“社群的幸福总值”。 79实际上，讨价还价是功利主义的核心，这意味着不同行动者的利益之间以及权利之间都必须进行权衡。功利主义明确认为，几乎所有利益都是“可协商、可分割、可交换的”，正如黛博拉·布科扬尼斯所言。 80

Leaders play an essential role in the utilitarian story, as they are principally responsible for assessing their constituents’ desires and then cutting deals with groups and individuals to maximize the “aggregate stock of happiness of the community.”79 In effect, bargaining is at the core of utilitarianism, which means there will have to be trade-offs between the interests of different actors as well as between rights. There is a clear sense in utilitarianism that virtually all interests are, as Deborah Boucoyannis puts it, “negotiable, divisible, and exchangeable.”80

功利主义的世界并非一个个人热忱地恪守第一原则或道德真理的世界。人们主要关注的是追求幸福，而政府则关注如何取悦民众，从而制定政策来实现这一目标。有些人或许对人生重大问题充满热情，但并非所有人都如此，因为强烈的信念会使人们难以做出最大化所有人幸福所必需的权衡。虽然理性与决定什么能使人幸福关系不大，但理性对于找到最大化集体效用的最佳途径至关重要。因此，功利主义者非常重视工具理性。边沁明确地阐述了这一区别：“行动的目的是由希望和恐惧决定的；理性所做的只是找到并确定手段。” 81

The utilitarian world is not one where individuals are fervently committed to first principles or moral truths. Its people are mainly concerned with finding happiness, while the government is concerned with determining what pleases them so as to design policies to achieve that end. Some people may have strong passions about life’s big questions, but not many can have them, simply because passionate beliefs would make it difficult to make the trade-offs necessary for maximizing everyone’s happiness. While reason has little to do with determining what makes people happy, reason matters greatly for figuring out the best way to maximize collective utility. Utilitarians therefore place great emphasis on instrumental rationality. Bentham makes this distinction clear: “It is by hopes and fears that the ends of action are determined; all that reason does is to find and determine the means.”81

功利主义者通常对建立一个和平繁荣的社会的前景持乐观态度。他们的乐观很大程度上源于这样一种信念：大多数人都是聪明理智的，因此有能力……做正确的事。詹姆斯·密尔精辟地概括了这种观点：“当各种结论及其证据以同样的谨慎和技巧呈现时，即使少数人可能被误导，也存在一种道德上的确定性，即大多数人会做出正确的判断，而最有力的证据，无论是什么形式，都会产生最大的影响。” 82 换句话说，公众舆论是一股强大的向善力量。此外，功利主义者持有进步的历史观，这进一步强化了他们的信念，即人们终将意识到自身利益的和谐性。正如约翰·斯图亚特·密尔所指出的，功利主义“建立在人类作为进步存在者的永恒利益之上。” 83

Utilitarians are generally optimistic about the prospects of creating a peaceful and prosperous society. Much of their optimism comes from the belief that most people are intelligent and reasonable and thus capable of doing the right thing. James Mill succinctly summarizes this perspective: “When various conclusions are, with their evidence, presented with equal care and with equal skill, there is a moral certainty, though some few may be misguided, that the greatest number will judge right, and the greatest form of evidence, whatever it is, will produce the greatest impression.”82 In other words, public opinion is a powerful force for good. Moreover, utilitarians have a progressive view of history, which further reinforces their belief that people will realize they have a harmony of interests. As John Stuart Mill notes, utilitarianism is “grounded on the permanent interests of man as a progressive being.”83

在功利主义中，国家的主要角色是管理博弈过程。政府必须关注诸如财富和资源如何分配以及哪些权利应优先于其他权利等重要事项。这并非一个依赖“看不见的手”来产生有利结果的自由放任国家：这里的“手”是可见的、干预性的，并且积极参与社会工程。然而，功利主义者并不十分强调国家扮演“守夜人”的角色，主要是因为他们认为对于何为美好生活并无本质区别。相反，国家的主要职能是确保每个人都能获得公平的机会，并最终实现自身幸福的最大化。84

The state’s principal role in utilitarianism is to manage the bargaining process. The government must be concerned with important matters like determining how wealth and resources are distributed and which rights should be privileged over others. This is not a laissez-faire state that depends on the invisible hand to produce favorable outcomes: the hand here is visible, interventionist, and actively engaged in social engineering. Utilitarians, however, do not place much emphasis on the state acting as a night watchman, mainly because they do not believe there are profound differences about what constitutes the good life. Instead, the state’s main function is to ensure that everyone gets a fair shake and ends up maximizing their pleasure.84

总之，功利主义与政治自由主义在本质上有所不同，因此不在本书的讨论范围之内。

In sum, utilitarianism differs in essential ways from political liberalism and thus falls outside this book’s purview.

自由主义理想

Liberal Idealism

自由主义理想主义是另一种被一些人归类为自由主义理论的思潮。它的创始人是英国哲学家T·H·格林，他在英国的众多追随者包括伯纳德·博桑奎特、L·T·霍布豪斯、J·A·霍布森和D·G·里奇。两位撰写国际政治著作的重要自由主义理想主义者是吉尔伯特·默里和阿尔弗雷德·齐默恩。20世纪初美国最重要的自由主义理想主义者是约翰·杜威，他深受格林著作的影响。这种理论方法在当代盎格鲁-撒克逊世界得以延续。杰拉尔德·高斯、斯蒂芬·马塞多和杰克·克里滕登等学者都持这种观点。克里滕登在《超越个人主义》（1992）一书中写道：“我在此提出的自由主义观点——超越个人主义的自由主义——……是对T·H·格林及其追随者……以及约翰·杜威在美国所进行的自由主义‘修正’的延续。” 87

Liberal idealism is another ism that some classify as a liberal theory. Its founding father is the British philosopher T. H. Green,85 whose many followers in Britain included Bernard Bosanquet, L. T. Hobhouse, J. A. Hobson, and D. G. Ritchie. The two key liberal idealists who wrote about international politics were Gilbert Murray and Alfred Zimmern. The leading liberal idealist in the United States in the early twentieth century was John Dewey, who was deeply influenced by Green’s writings.86 This theoretical approach has been carried on in the contemporary Anglo-Saxon world by scholars such as Gerald Gaus, Stephen Macedo, and Jack Crittenden, who writes in Beyond Individualism (1992): “The view of liberalism that I am offering here—liberalism beyond individualism—is . . . a continuation of the ‘revisioning’ of liberalism undertaken by T. H. Green and his disciples . . . and by John Dewey in America.”87

为什么自由主义理想主义者只是徒有自由主义之名？

Why Liberal Idealists Are Liberals in Name Only

毫无疑问，自由主义理想主义者正如其名，的确是理想主义者，但他们并非政治上的自由主义者。他们的理论中容不下自由主义毫不含糊的个人主义及其所伴随的不可剥夺的权利信念。自由主义理想主义者强调，人类首先是社会性动物。格林认为，“脱离社会关系的人……根本就不能称之为人。” 88或者，正如杜威所说，只有通过“为共同利益而努力，个体人类才能实现其真正的个性，并获得真正的自由。” 89

There is little doubt that liberal idealists are literally idealists, as the label indicates, but they are not political liberals. There is no room in their theory for liberalism’s unambiguous individualism and its accompanying belief in inalienable rights. Liberal idealists emphasize that human beings are first and foremost social animals. According to Green, men in “detachment from social relations . . . would not be men at all.”88 Or, as Dewey put it, only by working “for the common good can individual human beings realize their true individualities and become truly free.”89

格林和杜威的评论清楚地表明，尽管自由主义理想主义者致力于尽可能地维护个人自由，但他们首先将个人视为社会人。正是这种观点吸引他们走向黑格尔，黑格尔显然对这一传统中几乎所有早期思想家都产生了重要影响。当然，黑格尔持有一种有机社会观，尽管他也非常重视个人权利。正如他著名的著作《法哲学原理》所阐明的那样，他认为个人自由和社会统一并非相互矛盾，而是可以结合起来，从而形成一个充满活力的政治共同体。

Green’s and Dewey’s comments make it clear that although liberal idealists are committed to maintaining as much individual freedom as possible, they see individuals above all else as social beings. This view is what attracted them to Hegel, who was clearly an important influence on virtually all the early thinkers in this tradition. Hegel, of course, has an organic view of society, although he also cares much about individual rights. As is clear from his famous tract The Philosophy of Right, he believes individual freedom and social unity are not at odds with each other but can be joined together to produce a vibrant body politic.90

少数自由主义理想主义者——其中以霍布豪斯和霍布森最为著名——赞同黑格尔的观点，即可以设计一个有机社会，使公民能够最大限度地利用其个人权利。但这种对立面的融合是不可能的。自由主义和自由主义理想主义看待个人与社会关系的方式截然相反。任何致力于促进社会团结的国家都必须对自由或权利施加重要的限制。这并非意味着自由主义理想主义中没有权利，而是说，如果社会要促进公民之间的相互依存与合作，而不是旨在最大化个人效用的利己行为，那么权利就必须在某些重要方面受到限制。91

A few liberal idealists—Hobhouse and Hobson being the most prominent—agree with Hegel that it is possible to design an organic society that allows its citizens to take maximum advantage of their individual rights. But that merger of opposites is not possible. Liberalism and liberal idealism look at the relationship between individuals and their society in contradictory ways. Any country committed to promoting social unity has to place significant limits on freedom or rights. It is not that rights have no place in liberal idealism but that they must be circumscribed in important ways if the society is to foster interdependence and cooperation among its citizens rather than egoistic behavior designed to maximize individual utility.91

鉴于社会在自由主义理想主义思想中的首要地位，以及19世纪后半叶民族主义情绪在欧洲日益增长的影响力，爱国主义在许多自由主义理想主义者的著作中占据显著地位也就不足为奇了。他们将爱国主义视为一种向善的力量，一种凝聚社会的有效手段。例如，博桑奎特声称爱国主义是“一种巨大的自然力量，一种神奇的魔力”，它源于“家庭和亲属——血缘纽带”，而格林则推崇两位当代英国学者所称的“世界主义民族主义”。 92格林认为，“对人类的爱……需要具体化，才能对生活和行动产生任何影响。” 93

Given the primacy of society in liberal idealist thinking, coupled with the increasing influence of nationalist sentiment in Europe during the latter half of the nineteenth century, it is not surprising that patriotism figures prominently in the writings of many liberal idealists. They treated it as a force for good, as a highly effective means of unifying a society. Bosanquet, for example, claims that patriotism is “an immense natural force, a magical spell,” which grows from “family and kindred—the tie of blood,” while Green extols what two contemporary British scholars call “cosmopolitan nationalism.”92 For Green, “the love of mankind . . . needs to be particularized in order to have any power over life and action.”93

E·H·卡尔认为，自由主义理想主义者对民族主义抱持轻松态度的原因之一是，当时国家数量不多，因此它们“尚未明显地相互冲突”。94卡尔的观点或许不无道理，但民族主义之所以广受推崇，也因为它被视为体现了人民主权，而人民主权与民主密切相关。 95在世纪之交前后，民族主义在推翻欧洲各地王朝统治方面发挥了关键作用。致力于“教育民族化”的杜威在文中捕捉到了这种观点：“民族国家的建立，以情感和目标的统一、广袤区域的自由交往取代了以往的地方孤立、猜忌、嫉妒和仇恨。它迫使人们摆脱狭隘的地域主义，融入更大的社会单元，并使人们对一个将琐碎和自私利益置于次要地位的国家产生忠诚。” 96

E. H. Carr maintains that one reason for the liberal idealists’ blithe view of nationalism was that there were not many nations at the time, so they “were not yet visibly jostling one another.”94 While Carr is probably correct, nationalism was also widely admired because it was seen to embody popular sovereignty, which is closely tied to democracy.95 It played a key role before and after the turn of the century in toppling dynastic rulers all across Europe. Dewey, who was deeply committed to “nationalizing education,” captures this perspective when he writes: “The upbuilding of national states has substituted a unity of feeling and aim, a freedom of intercourse, over wide areas for earlier local isolations, suspicions, jealousies and hatreds. It has forced men out of narrow sectionalisms, into membership in a larger social unit, and created loyalty to a state which subordinates petty and selfish interests.”96

随着时间的推移，尤其是在第一次世界大战之后，自由主义理想主义者越来越意识到民族主义的阴暗面。1916年，杜威对比了民族主义的“积极方面”和“邪恶方面”；两年后，齐默恩以“真假民族主义”为题，撰写了一本关于促进国际和平的书籍，其中一章的标题便是“真假民族主义”。 97然而，自由主义理想主义者总体上仍然将民族主义视为一种积极的力量。例如，齐默恩在同一本书中写道：“正确理解和珍视的民族主义是一种伟大的、鼓舞人心的、赋予生命的力量，它既是抵御沙文主义的堡垒，也是抵御物质主义的堡垒——它抵御着所有那些骚扰和腐蚀现代人心灵和灵魂的、丧失文明的非人格化力量。” 98鉴于自由主义理想主义对社会的有机理解，它与民族主义完美契合。

Over time, and surely after World War I, liberal idealists grew more aware of nationalism’s dark side. In 1916, Dewey contrasted the “good aspect of nationalism” with its “evil side”; two years later, Zimmern used “True and False Nationalism” as the title of a chapter of a book about promoting international peace.97 Nonetheless, liberal idealists continued to view nationalism, on balance, as a positive force. In the same book, for example, Zimmern writes: “Nationalism rightly understood and cherished is a great uplifting and life-giving force, a bulwark alike against chauvinism and against materialism—against all the decivilising impersonal forces which harass and degrade the minds and souls of modern men.”98 Given liberal idealism’s organic conception of society, it fits neatly with nationalism.

政治自由主义者，尤其是权宜之计自由主义者，与自由理想主义者之间的一个共同点是他们对权力过大的国家感到担忧。黑格尔崇敬国家，称其为“具体自由的现实”。99正如我们将在下一章看到的，国家在民族主义中也扮演着核心角色。鉴于自由理想主义与黑格尔和民族主义的密切联系，人们可能会认为自由理想主义者会支持一个强大的国家，拥有充足的能力为了公共利益而干预公民社会。但事实上，他们只是勉强接受强权国家的概念，并且往往担心权力过大的国家会带来严重的麻烦。这也是自由理想主义者没有完全接受黑格尔思想的原因之一。100

One point of agreement between political liberals, especially modus vivendi liberals, and liberal idealists concerns their fear of a too-powerful state. Hegel revered the state, calling it “the actuality of concrete freedom.”99 The state also plays a central role in nationalism, as we will see in the next chapter. Given liberal idealism’s close links with both Hegel and nationalism, one would expect liberal idealists to favor a formidable state with abundant capacity to intervene in civil society for the common good. In fact, they embrace the notion of a strong state only reluctantly and tend to worry that a state with too much power will bring serious trouble. This is one reason liberal idealists do not fully embrace Hegel’s teachings.100

为什么自由主义理想主义者是理想主义者

Why Liberal Idealists Are Idealists

自由主义理想主义者世界观中蕴含的理想主义体现在他们根深蒂固的信念中，即政治的本质在于追求道德上的善。对他们而言，重要的是“人类的道德进步”，而非追求幸福最大化的功利主义目标。101格林轻蔑地将功利主义描述为“享乐主义的宿命论”。102他在著名的政治义务讲座开篇便说道：“我的目的是考察法律，或国家强制执行的权利和义务体系所服务的道德功能或目标，并在此过程中发现服从法律的真正基础或正当性。” 103

The idealism embedded in the liberal idealists’ worldview is reflected in their deep-seated belief that politics is about the pursuit of moral goodness. What matters for them is the “moral progress of man,” not the utilitarian goal of maximizing happiness.101 Green contemptuously described utilitarianism as “Hedonistic fatalism.”102 He began his famous lectures on political obligation by saying: “My purpose is to consider the moral function or object served by law, or by the system of rights and obligations which the state enforces, and in so doing to discover the true ground or justification for obedience to law.”103

其他自由主义理想主义者也像格林一样强调道德，尽管没有人能够确切地说明“道德理想”究竟是什么样子，或者“完善人”究竟包含哪些内容。104或许最好的答案是霍布豪斯的观点，即“理想社会被构想为一个整体，它依靠其各个部分的和谐发展而生存和繁荣，每个部分在按照自身路线和自身特性发展的同时，整体上也倾向于促进其他部分的发展。” 105 然而，这对于未来的政治生活来说仍然是一个相当模糊的方案。因此，格林承认自己无法确定人类完善的具体形态也就不足为奇了：“但是……虽然我们无法说，作为道德生活动力的理念所追求的人类完善，在实际实现中会是什么样子，但我们可以辨别出一些条件，如果要实现这一理念，就必须满足这些条件。” 106

Other liberal idealists shared Green’s emphasis on morality, although none could ever state what exactly the “moral ideal” looks like or what was involved in the “perfecting of man.”104 Probably the best answer is Hobhouse’s claim that “the ideal society is conceived as a whole which lives and flourishes by the harmonious growth of its parts, each of which in developing on its own lines and in accordance with its own nature tends on the whole to foster the development of others.”105 Still, this is a rather vague prescription for future political life. Thus, it is not surprising that Green acknowledged his inability to nail down what human perfectibility would look like: “But while . . . it is impossible for us to say what the perfecting of man, of which the idea actuates the moral life, in its actual attainment might be, we can discern certain conditions which, if it is to satisfy the idea, it must fulfill.”106

自由主义理想主义者也根深蒂固地相信理性是实现道德至善的关键工具。功利主义者同样重视理性，但两者之间存在微妙的差别。功利主义者往往带有精英主义色彩，因为他们对统治精英的智力能力抱有极大的信心，而这些精英正是功利主义事业核心——各种交易——的主要制定者。自由主义理想主义者似乎更相信普通民众能够明智地运用批判性思维。正如A.D.林赛在格林《政治义务原则》的导言中所写：“格林和他的理想主义同道……对普通人的价值和尊严有着深刻的信念。” 107自由主义理想主义者总是民主的拥护者，而大多数功利主义者的热情则更为克制。

Liberal idealists also have a deep-rooted belief in reason as the key tool for realizing moral goodness. Utilitarians also privilege reason, but there is a subtle difference. Utilitarians tend to be elitists, in the sense that they have great faith in the mental faculties of the governing elites who are principally responsible for crafting the bargains at the heart of the utilitarian enterprise. Liberal idealists appear to have more faith in the common people’s ability to use their critical faculties in smart ways. As A. D. Lindsay writes in his introduction to Green’s Principles of Political Obligation: “Green and his fellow-idealists had . . . a profound belief in the worth and dignity of the ordinary man.”107 Liberal idealists are invariably champions of democracy, while most utilitarians’ enthusiasm is more restrained.

或许，论证理性如何助力构建理想社会的最雄辩的自由主义理想主义者当属杜威，他尤其看好普通民众的能力。他认为，只要给予合适的教育机会，“普通人就能在社会和政治智慧方面达到前所未有的高度”。 108如果将这些普通民众聚集起来，“众多合作个体的智慧累积”将把社会推向更高的高度。109他谴责暴力作为社会变革的工具，转而推崇“智慧作为社会行动的另一种方式”。110在杜威看来，“有组织的智慧”可以通过复兴“民主理想”来追求“真正的民主”，从而解决“民主危机”。 111

Perhaps the most eloquent liberal idealist on how reason can help build the ideal society is Dewey, who was especially bullish on ordinary people’s capabilities. He believed that given the right educational opportunities, “the average individual would rise to undreamed heights of social and political intelligence.”108 If those regular people were then brought together, “the cumulative intelligence of a multitude of cooperating individuals” would take society to even greater heights.109 He condemns violence as a tool of social change and instead extols “intelligence as an alternative method of social action.”110 For Dewey, “organized intelligence” can solve “the crisis in democracy” by resurrecting “democratic ideals” in pursuit of “genuine democracy.”111

最后，格林及其追随者的理想主义体现在他们对民族主义最终是一种良性力量的信念上。即使在第一次世界大战之后——在许多人看来，第一次世界大战与民族主义紧密相连——自由主义理想主义者也大多忽略了民族主义的阴暗面。这种观点体现在默里和齐默恩的著作中，他们致力于在两次世界大战之间的时期促进国际和平。 112他们希望构建一个国际社会，让各大强国合作，共同改善彼此的境况。在他们的论述中，民族主义是一股重要的积极力量，正如齐默恩所言：“通往国际主义的道路在于民族主义；任何国际主义理论或理想，除非建立在对民族情感在人类生活中所占据并必须始终占据的地位的正确理解之上，否则都无法对我们的思考有所助益，也无法在实践中发挥作用。” 113更广泛地说，齐默恩和其他自由主义理想主义者认为，理性的力量可以抑制激烈的争论，使国际体系中的国家像社会中的个人一样，实现利益的自然和谐。

Finally, the idealism of Green and his followers is reflected in their belief in nationalism as ultimately a benign force. Even in the aftermath of World War I, which was linked with nationalism in many people’s minds, the dark side of that ism was largely shunted aside by liberal idealists. This approach is reflected in the writings of Murray and Zimmern, who were deeply committed to fostering international peace in the interwar period.112 They hoped to construct an international society in which the great powers would cooperate to improve each other’s lot. Nationalism was a major force for good in their story, as reflected in Zimmern’s comment that “the road to internationalism lies through nationalism; and no theory or ideal of internationalism can be helpful in our thinking or effective in practice unless it is based on a right understanding of the place which national sentiment occupies and must always occupy in the life of mankind.”113 More generally, for Zimmern and other liberal idealists, the power of reason kept passionate disagreements at bay, allowing states in the international system, like individuals in a society, to realize a natural harmony of interests.

因此，默里和齐默恩认为没有必要建立一个凌驾于无政府状态之上、依靠军事力量和法律强制力来约束列强的强大国际联盟，正如他们认为没有必要建立一个强大的国家来阻止个人和群体之间的互相残杀一样。相反，正如珍妮·莫菲尔德所说，他们将国际联盟视为“人类社会凝聚力自然延伸的结果”。 114这种观点或许可以被恰当地描述为理想主义，甚至可以说是乌托邦式的。

Thus, Murray and Zimmern saw no need for a commanding League of Nations that would transcend anarchy and police the great powers through military might and the force of law, any more than they saw the need for a powerful state to keep individuals and groups from killing each other. Instead, as Jeanne Morefield puts it, they saw the League as “a natural extension of humanity’s tendency toward social cohesion.”114 This view may be fairly described as idealistic, if not utopian.

显而易见，自由主义理想与政治自由主义有着根本性的差异。自由主义理想主义者不仅将人视为本质上的社会性动物，而且不相信天赋人权，并将民族主义置于其思想体系的重要地位。他们认为理性能够促进道德进步，引领人们走向某种“理想社会”。这些信念与政治自由主义的核心理念相冲突——而政治自由主义本身也值得深入批判。

It should be clear that liberal idealism differs in fundamental ways from political liberalism. Not only do liberal idealists view humans as essentially social animals, they also do not believe in natural rights and assign nationalism an important place in their story. They believe reason can help facilitate moral progress, leading the way toward some kind of “ideal society.” These beliefs conflict with the core notions that underpin political liberalism—an ideology that merits an extended critique of its own.

4

4

自由主义大厦的裂缝

Cracks in the Liberal Edifice

政治自由主义的两个最显著特征也是其两个重大缺陷：过分强调个人主义，以及过分重视不可剥夺的权利。正如我们所见，当代自由主义在很大程度上等同于进步自由主义，尽管权宜之计式的自由主义仍然影响着政治生活的轮廓。本章中我对政治自由主义的批判同样适用于这两种变体，因为它们在对个人主义和权利的重视程度上几乎没有差别。本章旨在评估自由主义作为一种政治意识形态。自由民主国家的外交政策以及更广泛的国际关系问题，将在后续章节中讨论。

TWO OF POLITICAL LIBERALISM’S MOST salient features are also its two significant flaws: the prominence it accords individualism, and the weight it places on inalienable rights. Contemporary liberalism, as we saw, is largely synonymous with progressive liberalism, although modus vivendi liberalism still affects the contours of political life. My criticisms of political liberalism in this chapter apply equally to both variants, as there is little daylight between them regarding the importance they ascribe to individualism and rights. In this chapter I am concerned with assessing liberalism as a political ideology. A liberal democracy’s foreign policy, and international relations more generally, are reserved for later chapters.

自由主义的首要问题在于它错误地假定人类本质上是孤独的个体，而事实上，人类的核心是社会性动物。这种对个人主义的过度推崇导致政治自由主义者忽视民族主义，而民族主义是一种极具影响力的政治意识形态，对世界各国都具有深远的影响。因此，自由主义的命运与民族主义紧密相连。尽管这两种主义在重要方面存在差异，但它们可以在一个国家内部共存。然而，一旦发生冲突，民族主义几乎总是占据上风。简而言之，民族主义严重限制了自由主义的影响力，包括其对自然权利的强调。

The first problem with liberalism is that it wrongly assumes that humans are fundamentally solitary individuals, when in fact they are social beings at their core. This commitment to far-reaching individualism leads political liberals to downplay nationalism, which is an especially powerful political ideology with profound influence inside every country in the world. Liberalism’s fate is therefore bound up with nationalism. Although these two isms differ in important ways, they can coexist inside a country’s borders. But when they are at odds, nationalism wins almost every time. In short, nationalism places serious limits on liberalism’s influence, including its emphasis on natural rights.

自由主义的第二个问题是，它关于个人权利的论述缺乏说服力。它声称权利不可剥夺，而且这种说法本身就站不住脚。认为几乎每个人都应该能够认识到权利的普遍性和重要性是“不言而喻”的，这种说法并不令人信服。权利对人们日常生活的影响远没有自由主义者想象的那么深远，但这并非意味着权利完全无关紧要。但即便在美国这样自由主义根深蒂固的国家，权利的影响也是有限的。

Liberalism’s second problem is that its story about individual rights is not persuasive. The claim that rights are inalienable and that this is “self-evident,” that almost everyone should be able to recognize both the universality and importance of rights, is not compelling. The influence of rights in people’s daily lives is nowhere near as profound as liberals seem to think, which is not to say rights are of no concern at all. But their impact is limited, even in places like the United States, where liberalism is deeply wired into the culture.

这些缺陷绝非致命。它们也并未从根本上削弱自由主义，因为它仍然拥有许多重要的优点。然而，这些缺陷表明，自由主义塑造任何国家日常生活的能力都将受到限制。正如我将在下一章论述的那样，这些限制在国际体系中更为显著。在此，我将聚焦于民族国家，最后探讨自由主义国家可能本质上难以运作的可能性，因为其内部各派系有强烈的动机永久掌控国家，并阻止其他派系夺取政权。虽然这一论点不容轻视，但成熟的自由民主政体确实具备一些有助于缓解这一问题的特征，但它们并非万无一失。

These shortcomings are by no means fatal. Nor do they cripple this ism in any meaningful way, as it still has a number of important virtues. What these flaws show, however, is that liberalism’s ability to shape daily life inside any country will encounter limits. And as I will argue in the next chapter, those limits are even more pronounced in the international system. Here I will stay within the nation-state, concluding with a discussion of the possibility that liberal countries might be intrinsically unworkable because the factions within them have strong incentives to capture the state permanently and prevent rival factions from taking the reins of power. While this argument should not be taken lightly, mature liberal democracies have certain features that go a long way toward ameliorating this problem, but they are not foolproof.

民族主义问题

The Nationalism Problem

自由主义最重要的缺陷在于其极端个人主义。它几乎完全关注个人及其权利，却忽视了人类生于大型群体，并在其中生活的事实。这些群体塑造了人类的本质，并决定了他们的忠诚。大多数人从始至终都或多或少带有部落属性，而这一点在自由主义的论述中却被严重忽略。

Liberalism’s most important shortcoming is its radical individualism. In focusing almost exclusively on individuals and their rights, it pays little attention to the fact that human beings are born into and operate in large collectivities, which help shape their essence and command their loyalties. Most people are at least partially tribal from the start to the finish of their lives, a point that is largely absent from the liberal story.1

对于世界上绝大多数人来说，国家是具有真正意义的最高层级社会群体。国家是由众多拥有共同点且对群体有着强烈忠诚感的人群组成的。个人作为国家成员生活，这从根本上塑造了他们的身份认同和行为。重视自决权并关注自身生存的国家渴望建立自己的国家。与此同时，国家本身也有充分的理由希望其人民组织成一个国家，这使得它们扮演着至关重要的角色。将民族与国家融合在一起。因此，世界上遍布民族国家也就不足为奇了，民族国家正是民族主义的化身。

The nation is the highest-level social group of real significance for the vast majority of people around the world. Nations are large collections of people who have much in common and who also have a powerful allegiance to the group. Individuals live as members of a nation, which fundamentally shapes their identities and behavior. Nations, which privilege self-determination and worry about their survival, want their own state.2 At the same time, states themselves have powerful reasons for wanting their people to be organized into a nation, which leads them to play a critical role in fusing the nation and the state together. Thus it is no surprise that the world is populated with nation-states, the embodiment of nationalism.

如果自由主义和民族主义都是当今世界一股强大的力量，那么它们之间究竟存在怎样的关系？有三点值得注意。首先，民族主义在每个国家都发挥着作用，这体现在我们生活在一个由民族国家组成的世界。然而，自由主义并非无处不在。真正的自由民主国家从未在国际体系中占据多数地位。其次，鉴于民族主义的普遍性，自由主义必然与民族主义共存。一个不以民族国家为核心的自由主义国家是不可能的，因此，自由主义本质上也是民族主义的。换言之，自由主义的运作离不开民族国家的框架。最后，自由主义一旦与民族主义发生冲突，必然会失败。

If liberalism and nationalism are both powerful forces in our world, what is the relationship between them? Three points are in order. First, nationalism is at play in every country, which is reflected in the fact that we live in a world of nation-states. Liberalism, however, is not a powerful force everywhere. True liberal democracies have never made up a majority of states in the international system. Second, given nationalism’s pervasiveness, liberalism must always coexist with nationalism. It is impossible to have a liberal state that is not a nation-state and thus nationalist to its core. Liberalism, in other words, operates within the confines of nation-states. Finally, liberalism invariably loses when it clashes with nationalism.

什么是民族主义？

What Is Nationalism?

民族主义是一种解释世界各地人民社会和政治组织方式的理论。它认为，人类社会被划分为许多不同的民族，每个民族都由具有强烈群体忠诚感的人们组成。除了家庭之外，对国家的忠诚通常凌驾于个人身份认同的所有其他形式之上。此外，一个民族的成员致力于最大限度地维护其民族的自主权，这意味着他们更倾向于拥有自己的国家。正如欧内斯特·盖尔纳所言，民族主义“认为政治单位和民族单位应该一致”。³这并非意味着每个民族都能拥有自己的国家，但鉴于他们对自决的渴望，这无疑是最终目标。与此同时，国家有强大的动机去治理组成民族的人民，这促使政治领导人努力促进民族主义的发展。民族主义既是一种自下而上的现象，也是一种自上而下的现象。

Nationalism is a theory that explains how people around the world are organized socially and politically. It holds that the human population is divided into many different nations composed of people with a strong sense of group loyalty. With the possible exception of the family, allegiance to the nation usually overrides all other forms of an individual’s identity. Furthermore, members of a nation are deeply committed to maximizing their nation’s autonomy, which means they prefer to have their own state. As Ernest Gellner famously put it, nationalism “holds that the political and the national unit should be congruent.”3 This is not to say that every national group can have its own state, but that is the ultimate goal, given their yearning for self-determination. States, meanwhile, have powerful incentives to govern people who are organized into nations, which leads political leaders to work hard to foster nationalism. Nationalism is both a bottom-up and a top-down phenomenon.

在通俗话语中，民族主义有时被认为反映了“古老的仇恨”，这暗示着它在有记载的历史中一直困扰着地球。这种看法是错误的：民族主义是一种近代现象。它最早出现在18世纪下半叶的欧洲，并由此扩展到北美，尽管在此之前它已在欧洲酝酿。自由主义实际上比民族主义早大约一个世纪出现在欧洲。此外，尽管民族主义会导致仇恨，但它并非总是能够消除仇恨。这只是复杂现象的一个方面，这种现象既有积极的一面，也有消极的一面。

In popular discourse, nationalism is sometimes said to reflect “ancient hatreds,” which implies it has plagued the planet for most of recorded history. This perception is false: nationalism is a recent phenomenon. It first emerged in Europe, and by extension North America, in the second half of the eighteenth century, although it was incubating in Europe before then.4 Liberalism actually came onto the European scene roughly a century before nationalism. Moreover, although nationalism can lead to hatred among peoples, that is only one facet of a complicated phenomenon that has positive as well as negative attributes.

要理解民族主义，最好的切入点是描述民族的基本特征，并阐明它与以往社会群体的区别。接下来，我将探讨民族为其成员履行的基本职能，民族为何渴望建立自己的国家，以及国家为何希望治理自己的国家。这些互补的动机促使民族与国家融合，这在很大程度上解释了民族主义为何如此强大。我还会阐述现代国家与之前的政治形式有何不同。

The best starting point for understanding nationalism is to describe the basic characteristics of a nation and show how it differs from prior social groups. I will then discuss the essential functions that nations perform for their members, why nations want their own state, and why states want to govern their own nation. These complementary incentives work to fuse the nation and state together, which accounts in good part for why nationalism is such a powerful force. I will also describe how the modern state differs from the political forms that preceded it.

什么是国家？

What Is a Nation?

国家具有六项基本特征，这些特征共同使国家区别于国家出现之前居住在地球上的其他类型的大型群体。5

Nations have six fundamental features that, taken together, distinguish them from the other kinds of large groups that inhabited the planet before nations came on the scene.5

合一感

一个民族是由众多具有强烈归属感的人群组成的大家庭，即便每个成员只认识少数其他国民。本尼迪克特·安德森将民族描述为“想象的共同体”，恰如其分地概括了这一特征。6民族之所以是想象的，是因为没有人真正了解其他成员，但几乎所有人都认同自己是这个共同体的一部分。他们对共同体的其他成员有着强烈的忠诚感，这意味着他们往往感到彼此负有责任，尤其是在与外部世界交往时。国民之间紧密的联系往往使得不同民族之间的界限清晰而牢固。7

A nation is a large community of people with a powerful sense of oneness, even though each member knows only a small number of fellow nationals. Benedict Anderson’s famous description of a nation as an “imagined community” nicely captures this feature.6 A nation is imagined in the sense that no person knows more than a tiny fraction of the other members, and yet almost all of them identify as part of a community. They have a strong sense of loyalty to the community’s other members, which means they tend to feel mutually responsible for each other, especially in dealing with the outside world. That the bonds among fellow nationals are tight tends to make the boundaries between different nations clear and firm.7

除了这种团结感之外，一个国家的成员也倾向于彼此平等相待。他们视自己为共同事业的一部分，尽管群体中有领导者和追随者，但无论处于顶层还是底层，最终都是同一个共同体的成员。安德森精辟地指出，尽管任何社会中总会存在各种形式的“不平等和剥削”，但“国家始终被视为一种深厚的、横向的同志情谊” 。

In addition to this sense of solidarity, a nation’s members also tend to treat each other as equals.8 They view themselves as part of a common enterprise, and although the group contains leaders and followers, the people at the top and those at the bottom are ultimately all members of the same community. Anderson captures this point when he notes that even though there will always be different kinds of “inequality and exploitation in any society, the nation is always conceived as a deep, horizontal comradeship.”9

在民族国家出现之前，欧洲各大社会群体成员之间的联系并不紧密。这些早期群体往往流动性很强，这意味着身份认同相对容易改变。历史学家帕特里克·吉里（Patrick Geary）曾论述罗马帝国崩溃后欧洲的社会生活：“四、五世纪见证了欧洲社会和政治结构的根本性变革。在此过程中，像哥特人这样的大联盟消失了，之后又在意大利和高卢以王国的形式重新出现。匈奴帝国或汪达尔王国等其他一些国家似乎凭空出现，却在几代人之后彻底消失。还有一些此前默默无闻的民族，例如盎格鲁人和法兰克人，崛起并建立了持久的政治实体。” 10 在民族主义时代，这种流动性是不可想象的，因为在民族主义时代，国家往往是紧密结合、界限分明的永久性实体。 11很难想象任何一个当代国家会消失，甚至经历吉里所描述的那种身份认同的快速转变。

Before the coming of nations, the bonds among members of the large social groups that populated Europe were not tight. Those earlier groups tended to be quite fluid, which meant that identities were relatively malleable. Consider the historian Patrick Geary’s discussion of social life in Europe after the collapse of the Roman Empire: “The fourth and fifth centuries saw fundamental changes in the European social and political fabric. In the process, great confederations like those of the Goths disappeared, to reemerge transformed into kingdoms in Italy and Gaul. Others like the Hunnic Empire or the Vandal kingdom seemed to spring from nowhere, only to vanish utterly in a few generations. Still other, previously obscure peoples, such as the Angles and the Franks, emerged to create enduring polities.”10 Such fluidity is unthinkable in the age of nationalism, in which nations tend to be tightly integrated, permanent entities separated by clear boundaries.11 It is hard to imagine any contemporary nation disappearing or even undergoing the sort of rapid transformation in its identity that Geary describes.

此外，早期社会群体内部并不存在平等意识。虽然一个国家内部不存在绝对的平等，但精英阶层与普通民众之间的差距显著缩小。民族国家出现之前的欧洲主要以农业为主，由两大阶级构成：贵族和农民。在罗马帝国时期、中世纪以及民族国家出现之前的王朝国家时期，贵族和农民之间的鸿沟都非常巨大。 12

Furthermore, there was no sense of equality within those earlier social groups. While there is not strict equality in a nation, there was a marked reduction in the gap between elites and their people. Pre-national Europe was largely agricultural and comprised two main classes: the aristocracy and the peasantry. The gulf separating them was huge, under the Roman Empire, during the Middle Ages, and in the era of dynastic states that preceded the appearance of nation-states.12

但到了十八世纪末，这种鸿沟已显著缩小，很大程度上是因为精英阶层和民众开始使用同一种语言交流，并将彼此视为拥有共同命运的共同事业的一部分。法国历史学家大卫·贝尔（David Bell）在描述这一转变时写道：“无论是维吉尔、黎塞留还是马扎林，都没有预料到会将整个社会——从优雅的朝臣到贫困的佃农，从博学的知识分子到城市乞丐——数百万人口融合为一个单一的民族，并彻底改变从语言到礼仪乃至最私密的观念的一切。” 13这种社会融合（尽管存在局限性）使人们倾向于感到彼此平等。

But by the late eighteenth century, the chasm had narrowed significantly, in good part because elites and their publics came to communicate in the same language and see themselves as part of a shared enterprise with a common destiny. The historian of France David Bell captures this transformation when he writes that “neither Virgil nor Richelieu or Mazarin envisioned taking entire populations—from elegant courtiers to impoverished sharecroppers, from well-polished intellectuals to urban beggars—and forging them all, in their millions into a single nation, transforming everything from language to manners to the most intimate ideas.”13 This melding of people in a society (which has its limits) inclines them to feel like equals.

这并非否认个人除了民族忠诚之外还拥有其他身份和忠诚。每个人都有多重身份：他们几乎人们总是隶属于各种组织和团体，拥有多重兴趣、友谊和责任。然而，除了家庭关系之外，一个人的最高忠诚几乎总是对其国家，而且这种忠诚通常在与其他忠诚发生冲突时凌驾于其他忠诚之上。例如，马克思主义者强调，个人最强烈的认同感来自于其社会阶级，无论是资本家、资产阶级还是工人阶级，这种认同感超越了民族认同。这种思想在《共产党宣言》中得到了清晰的体现，也解释了为什么一些马克思主义者认为，当欧洲各国政府在1914年开战时，欧洲的工人阶级不会互相残杀。他们发现，虽然社会阶级通常是一种强大的身份认同形式，但它与民族主义并不相同，民族主义倾向于通过赋予阶级更高的忠诚度来将不同阶级融合在一起。正如历史学家迈克尔·霍华德所言，“1914年号角吹响后，跨越国际边界的阶级团结呼吁便烟消云散”，世界各地的工人阶级与同胞并肩作战，对抗敌对的民族国家。 15 简而言之，民族认同并非个人拥有的唯一认同，但通常是最强大的认同。

None of this is to deny that individuals have other identities and loyalties besides national allegiance. Everyone has multiple identities: they almost always belong to a variety of organizations and groups, and have multiple interests, friendships, and commitments. Nevertheless, aside from family ties, a person’s highest loyalty is almost always to his nation, and that commitment usually overrides others when they conflict. Marxists, for example, emphasize that individuals identify most strongly with their social class, be it capitalists, the bourgeoisie, or the working class, and that this identification surpasses national identity. This thinking, clearly reflected in the Communist Manifesto, explains why some Marxists believed the working classes of Europe would not take up arms against each other when their governments went to war in 1914.14 They discovered that while social class is often a powerful form of identity, it is not in the same league as nationalism, which tends to fuse classes together by providing them with a higher loyalty. As the historian Michael Howard puts it, “The appeals for class unity across international frontiers were scattered to the winds once the bugles began to blow in 1914,” and the workers of the world fought with their fellow nationals against rival nation-states.15 In short, national identity is not the only identity an individual possesses, but it is generally the most powerful.

这并非否认一个国家中的个人有时会自私自利，利用其他成员。我们都曾遇到过这样的情况：如果像俗话说的“效用最大化者”那样行事，就能获得巨大利益。而自私的行为有时会导致同胞之间爆发激烈的冲突，甚至造成人员伤亡。然而，这种利己行为发生在国家内部，在这个国家里，个人对更广泛的社群负有义务，并且有充分的理由采取有利于集体的行为。当这两种逻辑发生冲突时，大多数人会将对国家的忠诚置于对自身的忠诚之上。

Nor is it to deny that individuals in a nation sometimes act in selfish ways and take advantage of other members. We all face situations where there is much to be gained by acting like the proverbial utility maximizer. And selfish behavior sometimes leads to bitter, even deadly, disputes between fellow nationals. Nevertheless, this kind of egoistic behavior takes place within a nation, where individuals have obligations to the wider community and where there are powerful reasons to act in ways that benefit the collective. When those two logics conflict, most people privilege loyalty to their nation over loyalty to themselves.

独特的文化

文化是区分不同国家的关键。每个国家都有一套独特的信仰和习俗，这些信仰和习俗为国民所共有，并使其区别于其他国家。习俗包括语言、仪式、规范、音乐和符号等，而信仰则涵盖宗教、基本的政治和社会价值观以及对历史的特定理解等。一个国家的成员在日常生活中往往以相似的方式行事和思考，这有助于加强彼此之间的联系。

What separates nations from each other is culture. Each nation has a distinct set of beliefs and practices that are shared by its members and that distinguish it from other nations. The practices involve things like language, rituals, codes, music, and symbols, while beliefs involve matters like religion, basic political and social values, and a particular understanding of history. The members of a nation tend to act and think in similar ways in their daily lives, and this helps foster strong bonds among them.

但要让构成一个民族国家的所有个体都拥有相同的习俗和信仰是不切实际的。相反，他们之间存在着相当程度的共性，但这种共性因具体情况而异。区分“厚文化”和“薄文化”是有意义的，这反映了一个国家文化多样性的程度。厚文化具有显著的文化同质性，而薄文化则更加多样化。主要由单一民族组成的民族国家，例如日本和波兰，拥有厚文化。而那些由核心民族和少数族裔组成的民族国家，例如加拿大、印度和西班牙，则拥有薄文化。16换句话说，在国家层面存在着一种薄的民族认同，但核心民族和少数族裔也拥有各自的认同。 17大多数社会的精英都希望塑造一种厚的民族认同，但这在包含两个或多个民族的社会中通常是不切实际的。尽管如此，研究表明，厚文化和薄文化的成员在“对国家成员身份的强烈认同感和自豪感”方面大致相同。 18

But it would be impracticable for all of the individuals who make up a nation-state to share the same practices and beliefs. There is instead a substantial commonality, which varies from case to case. It makes sense to distinguish between thick and thin cultures, which reflect the amount of cultural diversity a nation has. Thick cultures have significant cultural homogeneity, while thin cultures are more diverse. Nation-states that are largely composed of a single nation, such as Japan and Poland, have thick cultures. Those that have a core nation and minority nations, such as Canada, India, and Spain, have thin cultures.16 In other words, there is a thin national identity at the level of the state, but the core and minority nations also have their own identities.17 Most societies’ elites would like to mold a thick national identity, but that is usually not practical in societies containing two or more nations. Nevertheless, research shows that members of thick and thin cultures have roughly the same “degree of strong identity and pride in membership in the state.”18

要概括哪些文化特征能够区分不同的国家是不可能的。语言似乎是一个很好的标志，但不同的国家往往说着同一种语言。想想中美洲和南美洲所有讲西班牙语的国家就知道了。宗教也是如此。毕竟，天主教是奥地利、法国、意大利、葡萄牙和西班牙的主要宗教，这只是几个例子，而伊斯兰教则在整个阿拉伯世界占据主导地位。跨越文化的信仰和习俗表明，不同文化的定义特征可能存在相当大的重叠。德国和奥地利就是一个很好的例子。然而，它们之间也存在差异，这些差异在外人看来似乎微不足道，但两国人民却总是对此格外关注。西格蒙德·弗洛伊德曾将这种现象称为“微小差异的自恋”。 19

It is impossible to generalize about which cultural features allow us to distinguish one nation from another. Language might seem like a good marker, but different nations often speak the same language. Just think of all the countries in Central and South America that speak Spanish. The same is true of religion. Catholicism, after all, is the dominant religion in Austria, France, Italy, Portugal, and Spain, just to name a few examples, and Islam dominates throughout the Arab world. Beliefs and practices that cut across cultures show that different cultures’ defining features may overlap substantially. Germany and Austria are a good example. Nevertheless, they have differences as well, seemingly minor to outsiders but which the members of each nation invariably rivet on. Sigmund Freud famously called this phenomenon the “narcissism of minor differences.”19

人们或许会认为文化等同于族群，而族群有时被定义为一个群体沿袭至今的古老而固定的特征集合。根据这种原始主义观点，一个民族的根基在于其血统：即其共同的祖先，即生活在远古时代的亲属。然而，大型社会群体，尤其是民族，其发展演变的方式与这种族群定义相悖，这也是我在本书中不使用“族群”一词的原因。

One might also think that culture is synonymous with ethnicity, which is sometimes defined as a set of ancient, fixed characteristics of a group that have been carried forward to the present. According to this primordialist perspective, a nation’s roots are its bloodlines: its common descent from relatives who lived long ago. But large social groups, and nations in particular, have evolved in ways that contradict that definition of ethnicity, which is why I do not employ the term in this book.

文化并非一成不变，因为个人身份并非与生俱来。相反，它们是社会建构的，并且更具动态性。比原始主义者所认为的更为灵活。精英阶层往往在塑造一个国家的过程中扮演着关键角色，正如一位杰出的意大利领导人在1861年意大利统一之际所言：“我们已经缔造了意大利。现在我们必须缔造意大利人。” 20如果我确实要使用“族群”一词，我会采用马克斯·韦伯的定义，即“对……共同血统的主观信念”，或者对特定民族拥有共同文化传统的信念。 21这些定义与我的论述相符。

Cultures are not fixed because individual identities are not hardwired into people at birth. Instead, they are socially constructed and are more fluid than primordialists recognize. Elites often play a key role in shaping a nation, as reflected in this comment by a prominent Italian leader in 1861, when Italy was being unified: “We have made Italy. Now we have to make Italians.”20 If I did use the word ethnicity, I would use it in Max Weber’s sense, to mean “a subjective belief in . . . common descent,” or the belief that a particular people share a common cultural tradition.21 Those definitions are consistent with my story.

从本质上讲，民族性的真正基础是心理层面的，而非生物学层面的，这正是沃克·康纳所说的“民族的本质是无形的” 22 。当大量人群认为自己是同一个拥有独特文化的社会群体成员时，一个民族就存在了。换句话说，一个民族是一个庞大的群体，它自认为是一个民族 23，并且拥有对其共同身份至关重要的切实信仰和实践。一旦民族形成，它们就极难发生根本性的改变，部分原因是个人从出生起就被深度社会化到特定的文化中，并且通常习惯于并忠于该文化的信仰和实践。

In essence, the real basis of nationhood is psychological, not biological, which is why Walker Connor says “the essence of a nation is intangible.”22 A nation exists when a large number of people think of themselves as members of the same unique social group with a distinct culture. In other words, a nation is a large group that considers itself a nation23 and that has tangible beliefs and practices that matter greatly for its common identity. Once nations are formed, they are exceptionally resistant to fundamental change, partly because individuals are heavily socialized into a particular culture from birth, and typically accustomed to and committed to its beliefs and practices.

民族忠诚得以持久的另一个重要原因是：从口头传统到书面传统的转变。直到19世纪，大多数人都是通过口口相传了解自己所属社会群体的历史。当时识字的人寥寥无几，可供他们阅读的历史书籍也屈指可数。因此，为了适应新来者和不断变化的环境，人们相对容易修改关于过去的故事。然而，一旦一个群体的历史被记录在书籍中，就很难再根据新的情况进行修改。正如政治学家詹姆斯·斯科特所指出的，“纪念碑和文字的主要缺点恰恰在于它们的相对永久性。” 24在一个文字普及的世界里，人们在大型社会群体中的身份认同变得更加固定，界限也变得更加模糊。从口头文化到书面文化的转变不仅在欧洲新兴国家内部建立了更紧密的联系，也使这些社群更加稳固，更能抵御变革。

There is another important reason for the durability of national loyalties: the movement from oral to written traditions. Until the nineteenth century, most people learned about their social group’s history by word of mouth. Few people could read, and for them there were few popular history books. It was reasonably easy to change stories about the past to accommodate newcomers as well as shifting circumstances. But once a group’s history is written in books, it is difficult to change the story to suit new conditions. As the political scientist James Scott notes, “The key disadvantage of monuments and written texts is precisely their relative permanence.”24 In a literate world, people’s identities inside large social groups become more fixed, and boundaries become less fluid. The movement from an oral to a literate culture not only created tighter bonds within Europe’s burgeoning nations but also made those communities more robust and resistant to change.

优越感

无论其他国家如何行事，人们都为自己的国家感到自豪，因为那是他们的家园。但他们也会思考自己的国家与其他国家相比如何，尤其是那些与他们经常接触的国家。沙文主义通常随之而来。25大多数人认为自己的国家优于其他国家。他们认为自己的国家拥有特殊的品质，使其凌驾于其他国家之上。德国民族主义者约翰·费希特就曾这样评价道：“只有德国人……才能爱国；只有德国人才能为了自己的国家而包容全人类；与他相比，其他任何国家的爱国主义都必然是自私的、狭隘的，并且对全人类充满敌意。” 26 1848年英国的自由派外交大臣帕默斯顿勋爵也同样带有沙文主义色彩：“我们的职责——我们的使命——不是奴役，而是解放：我可以毫不夸张地说，我们站在道德、社会和政治文明的前沿。我们的任务是引领其他国家，指引它们的前进方向。” 27

Regardless of what other nations do, people take pride in their own nation because it is a home to them. But they also think about how their nation compares with other nations, especially those they interact with frequently. Chauvinism usually follows.25 Most people think their nation is superior to others. It has special qualities that merit its being privileged over other nations. The German nationalist Johann Fichte captures this perspective with his comment that “the German alone . . . can be patriotic; he alone can for the sake of his nation encompass the whole of mankind; contrasted with him from now on, the patriotism of every other nation must be egoistic, narrow and hostile to the rest of mankind.”26 Lord Palmerston, Britain’s liberal foreign secretary in 1848, was no less chauvinistic: “Our duty—our vocation—is not to enslave, but to set free: and I may say, without any vainglorious boast, or without great offence to anyone, that we stand at the head of moral, social and political civilization. Our task is to lead the way and direct the march of other nations.”27

不出所料，这种特殊感使一些国家认为自己受到了上帝的眷顾。这种信念在美国有着悠久的传统，可以追溯到清教徒时期。清教徒和许多美国人一样，相信上帝与美国之间存在着特殊的契约，上帝赋予了美国特殊的属性，使其人民比其他民族更聪明、更高尚。当然，一个人不必信仰上帝才能相信美国例外论。例如，伍德罗·威尔逊在说“美国的昭昭天命不是用武力统治世界……美国的命运和领导力在于引领世界思考”时，并没有提及上帝。28国务卿马德琳·奥尔布赖特在1998年发表著名言论时也没有诉诸上帝：“如果我们不得不使用武力，那是因为我们是美国。我们是不可或缺的国家。我们屹立不倒。我们目光长远。”正如莱因霍尔德·尼布尔所指出的，29美国人普遍认为自己是“人类在追求完美的旅程中的导师”。30所有这些都表明，美国人骨子里是民族主义者，尽管他们中的大多数人并不这样看待自己。

Unsurprisingly, this sense of specialness leads some nations to think they have been singled out by God. This belief has a rich tradition in the United States, going back to the Puritans, who believed, as many Americans have over time, that there is a special covenant between God and the United States, and that God has given it special attributes that make its people smarter and nobler than other peoples. Of course, one does not have to believe in God to believe in American exceptionalism. Woodrow Wilson, for example, made no reference to God when he said: “The manifest destiny of America is not to rule the world by physical force. . . . The destiny of America and the leadership of America is that she shall do the thinking of the world.”28 Nor did Secretary of State Madeleine Albright appeal to God when she famously said in 1998: “If we have to use force, it is because we are America. We are the indispensable nation. We stand tall. We see further into the future.”29 Americans, as Reinhold Niebuhr noted, generally believe they are “tutors of mankind in its pilgrimage to perfection.”30 All of this is to say Americans are nationalists to the core, even though this is not how most of them think of themselves.

国家有时会超越优越感，最终憎恨竞争对手。我称之为极端民族主义：认为其他国家不仅低人一等，而且危险，必须采取强硬甚至残酷的手段加以应对。在这种情况下，对“他者”的蔑视和仇恨充斥着整个国家，并产生强大的动机去消除这种威胁。以暴力。31然而，各国之间并非总是互相憎恨；有时他们相处得相当融洽。

Nations sometimes go beyond feeling superior to other nations and end up loathing their competitors. I call this hypernationalism: the belief that other nations are not just inferior but dangerous, and must be dealt with harshly or even brutally. In such cases, contempt and hatred of “the other” suffuses the nation and creates powerful incentives to eliminate that threat with violence.31 Yet nations do not always loathe each other; sometimes they get along quite well.

深厚的历史

历史对所有国家都至关重要，尽管它们往往更注重创造神话而非还原事实。各国编造英雄故事来贬低其他国家的成就，并以此强化自身特殊性的说法。正如斯蒂芬·范·埃弗拉所指出的，“沙文主义式的神话构建是民族主义的标志，几乎所有民族主义运动都在某种程度上运用了这种做法。” 32他认为，这些神话种类繁多。有些旨在美化过去的功绩，有些则是为了掩盖国家愚蠢或可耻的行为。还有一些神话通过贬低竞争对手或将本国过去或现在的问题归咎于他们来诋毁对手。但即便某些神话根本站不住脚，人们通常的反应仍然是捍卫国家，因为“这是我的国家，无论对错”。

History matters greatly for all nations, although they tend to emphasize creating myths rather than getting the facts right. Nations invent heroic stories about themselves to denigrate the achievements of other nations and buttress their claim that they are special. “Chauvinist mythmaking,” as Stephen Van Evera notes, “is a hallmark of nationalism, practiced by nearly all nationalist movements to some degree.”32 Those myths, he argues, come in different varieties. Some are meant to glorify past behavior, while others are invented to whitewash instances where the nation acted foolishly or shamefully. Other myths malign rival nations by making them look inferior or blaming them for the home nation’s past or present problems. But even when some myth proves impossible to sell, the usual response is to defend the nation anyway, because “it is my nation, right or wrong.”

民族也利用神话来论证其悠久的历史渊源，这在一定程度上解释了为什么民族有时会被定义为具有永恒的特征。大多数人都希望相信自己的国家拥有悠久而丰富的传统，尽管很少有人真正拥有这种传统。为了弥补这一缺陷，历史被篡改或重写。这种现象在19世纪的欧洲十分普遍，当时民族主义席卷整个地区，历史研究也逐渐成为一门学术学科。帕特里克·吉里（Patrick Geary）描述了其结果：“现代史诞生于19世纪，它被构想和发展成为欧洲民族主义的工具。作为民族主义意识形态的工具，欧洲各国的历史取得了巨大的成功，但它也把我们对过去的理解变成了一个充满毒素的垃圾场。” 33神话的构建与民族主义密不可分，这就是为什么欧内斯特·勒南（Ernest Renan）说：“历史错误是民族形成过程中的一个重要因素。” 34

Nations also employ myths to argue that they have ancient roots, which explains in part why ethnicity is occasionally defined in terms of timeless features. Most people want to believe their nation has a long and rich tradition, even though few do. History is altered or rewritten to remedy the problem. This phenomenon was commonplace in nineteenth-century Europe, when nationalism was sweeping the region and history was becoming a scholarly enterprise. Patrick Geary describes the result: “Modern history was born in the nineteenth century, conceived and developed as an instrument of European nationalism. As a tool of nationalist ideology, the history of Europe’s nations was a great success, but it has turned our understanding of the past into a toxic waste dump.”33 Mythmaking and nationalism go hand in hand, which is why Ernest Renan said, “Historical error is an essential factor in the creation of a nation.”34

神圣领土

民族总是认同特定的地理空间，并将其视为神圣领土。人们与他们视为合法家园的土地建立起深厚的情感联系。其主要目标是确立对该领土的主权，而这与民族认同密不可分。民族认同。如果这片想象中的家园的任何一部分丧失，民族成员几乎总是致力于将其收复。中国对台湾的态度就是一个很好的例子。在中国大陆，人们普遍且根深蒂固地认为台湾是中国的一部分，最终必须重新统一，尽管台湾人民在近几十年发展出了自己的身份认同，并希望台湾被视为一个主权国家。北京历届政府都强调，如果台湾宣布独立，中国将不惜开战，即使战争很可能对中国经济造成重大损害。36所有国家，不仅仅是中国，都执着于对他们认为是其神圣家园不可分割一部分的领土行使主权。

Nations invariably identify with specific geographical spaces, which they treat as sacred territory.35 People form a deep emotional attachment with land they perceive as their rightful homeland. The principal aim is to establish sovereignty over that territory, which is inextricably bound up with the nation’s identity. And if any part of that imagined homeland is lost, the nation’s members are almost always committed to recovering it. A good example is China’s attitude toward Taiwan. It is widely and deeply believed among mainland Chinese that Taiwan is a part of China and must eventually be reintegrated, even though the Taiwanese have developed their own identity in recent decades and want Taiwan to be treated as a sovereign nation-state. Successive governments in Beijing have emphasized that they would go to war if Taiwan declared itself an independent country, even though a war would likely do significant damage to China’s economy.36 All nations, not just China, are obsessed with exercising authority over the territory they believe is an integral part of their hallowed homeland.

在国家出现之前，大型社会群体也重视领土控制，但他们很少将领土视为神圣之地。领土的重要性主要体现在经济和军事方面。优质地段，包括欧洲的大部分土地，蕴藏着宝贵的资源，例如人力资源，这些资源对于建立强大的经济和军事力量至关重要。一些领土也具有重要的战略意义：它们提供了易守难攻的边界，或是通往重要水道或海洋的通道。这种工具主义的观点意味着，在适当的情况下，统治者可以将领土视为可分割的。但是，一个国家的领土作为其文化遗产的一部分，具有巨大的内在价值，这意味着它是不可分割的。 37

The large social groups that came before nations also cared about controlling territory, but they rarely viewed it as sacred space. Territory mattered largely for economic and military reasons. Prime real estate, which included much of the land in Europe, contained valuable resources, including manpower, that were essential for building a powerful economy and a formidable military force. Some territory was also strategically important: it provided defensible borders or access to an important waterway or ocean. This instrumental view meant that leaders could treat their territory as divisible under the right circumstances. But a nation’s territory holds enormous intrinsic value as part of its cultural heritage, which means it is indivisible.37

主权

最后，各国都力求最大限度地掌控自身的政治命运，换句话说，它们非常重视主权，或者说，非常重视国家内部以及国家之间的政治权力分配。在国内层面，主权指的是国家最高政治权力的归属。 38主权者拥有制定和执行内政外交政策的最终权力。39

Finally, nations aim to maximize their control over their own political fate, which is another way of saying they are deeply concerned about sovereignty, or how political authority is arranged inside a state as well as among states. In domestic terms, sovereignty denotes where supreme political authority lies within a state.38 The sovereign holds the ultimate authority to formulate and execute domestic as well as foreign policy.39

一个国家只能有一个主权者，因为主权是不可分割的。在大约1500年至1800年间遍布欧洲的王朝国家中，主权完全归于国王或女王，据说是由上帝赋予王冠的。因此，在那个时期，“君权神授”的说法十分普遍。但这种主权观与民族主义格格不入。在一个民族国家中，最高主权者……权力属于人民或国家。人民并非效忠君主的臣民，而是享有国家成员权利和义务的公民。因此，他们人人平等。

There can be only one sovereign within a state, as sovereignty is indivisible. In the dynastic states that populated Europe between roughly 1500 and 1800, sovereignty rested exclusively with the king or queen and was said to be conferred on the crown by God. Thus it was commonplace during that period to talk about the “divine right of kings.” But this perspective on sovereignty is incompatible with nationalism. In a nation-state, supreme authority resides in the people or the nation. The people are not subjects who owe allegiance to a monarch but citizens with the rights and responsibilities that come with being members of a nation. As such, they are all equals.

这种人民主权的概念在1791年的法国宪法中得到了清晰的体现，宪法规定：“主权​​是统一的、不可分割的、不可剥夺的、不可剥夺的；它属于国家；任何团体都不能将主权归于自身，任何个人也不能将其僭越。” 40这种对君主权威的挑战会让路易十五感到困惑，他曾说过：“有些人竟敢将国家视为与君主分离的独立实体，而国家的权利和利益必然与我的权利和利益紧密相连，它们只掌握在我手中。” 41（这不过是他前任那句著名宣言“国家，就是我！”的冗长版本罢了。）国际关系学者罗伯特·杰克逊写道，在民族主义兴起之前，“主权统治者关注的是领土，但对居住在这些领土上的人民却漠不关心，只要这些人民接受他们的统治。” 42国王和王后常常觉得他们与同僚君主之间的共同点比与他们统治下的人民之间的共同点更多。

This notion of popular sovereignty is clearly reflected in the French constitution of 1791, which states: “Sovereignty is one, indivisible, inalienable, and imprescriptible; it belongs to the Nation; no group can attribute sovereignty to itself nor can an individual arrogate it to himself.”40 That challenge to monarchial authority would have confounded Louis XV, who said, “The rights and interests of the nation, which some dare to regard as a separate body from the monarch, are necessarily united with my rights and interests, and they repose only in my hands.”41 (This is simply a more prolix version of his predecessor’s famous outburst, “L’etat, c’est moi!”) Before the coming of nationalism, writes the international relations scholar Robert Jackson, “sovereign rulers were preoccupied with territory but were largely indifferent to the peoples that occupied it, provided they accepted their authority.”42 Kings and queens often felt they had more in common with their fellow sovereigns than the populations under their control.

然而，人民主权的概念必须加以限定，因为一个国家几乎不可能集体做出政策决定，尤其是在紧急情况下，即使在正常时期也是如此。速度和效率要求在生死存亡的危机中，最高权力掌握在一个人或至多少数人手中。 43在更一般的情况下，决策可以由独裁者或民选领导人做出。然而，所有这些情况的关键特征是，决策者与人民有着密切的联系，并且相信他们是在代表人民行事。正如政治理论家伯纳德·亚克所写：“即使是威权主义和极权主义民族主义者也会援引人民主权来为其极端形式的民族主张辩护。” 44王朝统治者并不认为自己是其统治下人民的仆人，而是为自身利益或他们认为的国家利益服务。

The notion of popular sovereignty must be qualified, though, because it is virtually impossible for a nation to collectively make policy decisions, in an emergency especially, but also in normal times. Speed and efficiency demand that in an existential crisis, supreme authority rests with a single person or at most a few people.43 In more ordinary circumstances, decisions can be made by either autocrats or democratically elected leaders. The key feature in all of these circumstances, however, is that the decider or deciders have a close bond with their people and believe they are acting on the people’s behalf. As the political theorist Bernard Yack writes, “Even authoritarian and totalitarian nationalists invoke popular sovereignty to justify their demands for extreme forms of national assertion.”44 The dynastic sovereigns did not consider themselves servants of the populations they controlled, but instead acted to serve either their own interests or what they perceived to be the state’s interests.

在国际上，主权意味着国家希望拥有自主决定内政外交政策的能力，不受外部干涉。这一观点既适用于王朝国家，也适用于民族国家。当然，国际体系中的各种结构性力量会限制主权国家的选择范围，但主权要求其他国家不得蓄意干涉其政治。各国都坚定地致力于自决，而与国家密不可分的民族，无论是在与其他民族国家交往时，还是在本国内部，都高度重视自决。

Internationally, sovereignty means that the state wants the ability to make its own decisions on both domestic and foreign policy, free from outside interference. That viewpoint applies to both dynastic states and nation-states. Of course, various structural forces in the international system will limit a sovereign state’s menu of options, but sovereignty demands that other states not purposely intrude in its politics. States are deeply committed to self-determination, and nations, which are inextricably bound up with the state, care greatly about self-determination, both in dealing with other nation-states and inside their own states.

这种对自决的强调，加上民族主义固有的统一感，都指向了蕴含于这一主义中的民主冲动。罗伯斯庇尔曾写道：“只有在民主制度下，国家才能成为组成它的所有个人的祖国，并且其捍卫自身事业的积极分子人数才能与公民人数一样多。”45 但这并非意味着民族主义是民主的主要原因，因为它并非如此，但它是一个重要的促成因素。过去两个世纪以来，民主在全球大部分地区传播的同时，民族主义也在世界各地兴起，这绝非偶然。然而，需要注意的是，我讨论的是民族主义与民主的关系，而非与自由主义的关系。自由主义和民族主义有时会在根本层面发生冲突。

This emphasis on self-determination, coupled with the sense of oneness integral to nationalism, points us to the democratic impulse embedded in this ism.45 Robespierre captured the link between democracy and nationalism when he wrote: “It is only under a democracy that the state is the fatherland of all the individuals who compose it and can count as many active defenders of its cause as it has citizens.”46 This is not to say nationalism is the principal cause of democracy, because it is not, but it is an important contributing factor. It is no accident that over the past two centuries, democracy has spread across large portions of the globe at the same time that nationalism was gaining sway around the world. Note, however, that I am talking about nationalism’s relationship with democracy, not with liberalism. Liberalism and nationalism sometimes clash in fundamental ways.

总之，国家具有六个核心特征，这些特征共同使它们区别于国家出现之前主导社会格局的大型社会群体。这些特征包括：强烈的统一感、独特的文化、显著的特殊感、强调永恒性的历史叙事、对领土的深厚依恋以及对主权或自决的坚定承诺。

In sum, nations have six core features that, taken together, distinguish them from the kinds of large social groups that dominated the landscape before nations came on the scene. These features are a powerful sense of oneness, a distinct culture, a marked sense of specialness, a historical narrative that emphasizes timelessness, a deep attachment to territory, and a strong commitment to sovereignty or self-determination.

国家的基本职能

The Essential Functions of a Nation

国家以两种至关重要的方式服务于其成员：一是促进生存，二是满足重要的心理需求。在这方面，它们与前人并无二致，尽管具体机制略有不同。

Nations serve their members in two critically important ways: they facilitate survival and fulfill important psychological needs. In this they are no different from their predecessors, although the actual mechanics vary somewhat between them.

国家本质上是生存的载体。其文化基础使得成员国能够轻松有效地合作，从而最大限度地提高其获得基本生活必需品的机会。以语言为例，一个国家的大多数人民都说同一种语言，这使得他们能够轻松地沟通协作，共同实现重要的目标。目标。47一个国家的风俗习惯、礼仪和行为规范也是如此。合作也有助于建立可靠的安全部队，以便在成员国成员受到其他成员国或外部势力威胁时保护他们。一个国家的文化和民族认同感有助于其与其他国家划清界限，这也有助于识别和抵御外部势力。最后，各国非常重视自决权，部分原因是自决权使它们能够做出它们认为必要的决定，以保护自身免受敌对国家的侵害。

Nations are primarily survival vehicles. Their underlying culture allows members to cooperate easily and effectively, which in turn maximizes their chances of securing life’s basic necessities. Take language, for example. The fact that a nation’s people mostly speak the same language makes it easy for them to communicate and work together to achieve important goals.47 The same is true of a nation’s customs and rituals, and its behavioral norms. Cooperation also facilitates building reliable security forces that can protect individual members if they are threatened by another member or an outsider. A nation’s culture and sense of oneness help it create clear boundaries with other nations, which also help identify and protect against outsiders. Finally, nations care greatly about self-determination, in part because it allows them to make the decisions they think are necessary to protect them from rival nations.

但国家不仅仅是生存的工具。对大多数人来说，它们也满足了重要的情感需求。我们都是社会性动物，别无选择，只能归属于某个群体，但社会群体却有很多种。48一个国家之所以如此特别，是因为它提供了一种存在主义叙事。它赋予其成员一种强烈的归属感，让他们觉得自己是某个特殊而独特的共同体的一部分，这个共同体的历史充满了重要的传统以及杰出的人物和事件。换句话说，他们的文化是独特的。成员们希望共同生活，传承这些传统，“认可共同继承的遗产”，49并共享共同的命运。

But nations are more than survival vehicles. For most people, they also fulfill important emotional needs. We are all social animals and have little choice but to belong to groups, but there are many social groups.48 What makes a nation so special is that it provides an existential narrative. It gives its members a strong sense that they are part of an exceptional and exclusive community whose history is filled with important traditions as well as remarkable individuals and events. Their culture, in other words, is special. Members want to live together to carry on those traditions, “validate the heritage that has been jointly received,”49 and share a common destiny.

此外，国家向其成员承诺，将像过去一样，为子孙后代提供支持。从这个意义上讲，民族主义与宗教颇为相似，两者都巧妙地将过去、现在和未来编织成一张浑然一体的网络，使成员感受到自己是悠久而丰富的传统的一部分。这种对国家的崇敬成为一种强大的凝聚力，增强了国家的凝聚力，并提高了其生存前景。

Furthermore, nations promise their members that they will be there for future generations the way they were there in the past. In this sense, nationalism is much like religion, which also does an excellent job of weaving the past, present, and future into a seamless web that gives members a sense they are part of a long and rich tradition.50 This veneration of the nation acts as a formidable bonding force that enhances its cohesiveness and boosts its prospects for survival.

为什么国家需要建国

Why Nations Want States

到目前为止，我对民族国家的政治层面着墨不多，但正如我在第二章中所阐述的，所有大型社会群体，包括民族国家，从一开始就需要政治制度才能生存。对一个民族而言，拥有自己的国家是最佳选择。

So far I have paid little attention to the political dimension of nationhood, but as I explained in chapter 2, all large social groups, including nations, need political institutions from the beginning to survive. For a nation, the best possible situation is to have its own state.

那么，什么是国家？一些学者用这个术语来描述历史上几乎所有的高级政治机构。例如，查尔斯·蒂利在其开创性著作《强制、资本与欧洲国家，公元990-1992年》中写道：“五千多年来，国家一直是世界上规模最大、权力最强的组织。” 51如此宽泛的概念然而，这种定义未能涵盖历史上欧洲及其他地区存在的各种政治形式之间的重要差异。因此，我将“国家”一词限定为16世纪初在欧洲开始形成并最终遍及全球的特定政治实体。它与之前的众多政治形式有着显著的不同，这些形式包括（仅举几例）城邦、帝国、部落、公国、公爵领地、神权政体和封建君主制。在我的论述中，“国家”有两种形式：一种是约从1500年到1800年占据主导地位的王朝国家，另一种是取代它的民族国家。

What, then, is a state? Some scholars use the term to describe almost all of the higher political institutions that have existed over time. For example, Charles Tilly writes in his seminal book Coercion, Capital, and European States, AD 990–1992, “States have been the world’s largest and most powerful organizations for more than five thousand years.”51 Such a broad definition, however, fails to capture important differences among the widely varying political forms that have existed in Europe and other regions throughout history. Instead, I restrict the term state to the particular political entity that began to take shape in Europe during the early 1500s and eventually spread across the globe. It differs significantly from its many predecessors, which include (to name just a few) city-states, empires, tribes, principalities, duchies, theocracies, and feudal monarchies. The state in my story takes two forms: the dynastic state, which predominated from about 1500 to 1800, and the nation-state, which replaced it.

国家是一个政治机构，它控制着一片拥有明确边界的大片领土，并有能力运用武力来约束或惩戒生活在其边界内的个人和群体。52换言之，在这些边界之内，国家拥有“至高无上的权力，使其能够在领土范围内凌驾于下级行政机构之上，并无视私有财产”。53国家的决策是集中化的：权力集中在中央。实际上，这意味着一个国家拥有一个常设的官僚机构、一套规则和法律体系，以及向其境内居民征税的能力。最重要的是，中央政府控制着合法的暴力工具。当然，国家既关注内部事务，也关注外部事务，因此会与其他国家开展外交、经济往来、安全竞争以及战争。

A state is a political institution that controls a large territory with well-defined borders and has the ability to employ force to break or discipline the individuals and groups living within those borders.52 Within these borders, in other words, the state has “exclusive supreme command, enabling it within this territory, to overrule the lower administrative echelons as well as disregard private property.”53 Decision making is centralized in a state: power is concentrated at the center. In practical terms, this means a state has a permanent bureaucracy, a system of rules and laws, and the capacity to levy taxes on the people living within its borders. Most importantly, the central administration controls the lawful tools of violence. The state, of course, looks outward as well as inward, and thus engages in diplomacy, economic intercourse, security competition, and war with other states.

主权的概念诞生于欧洲王朝国家兴起之时，因此这些国家有时也被称为主权国家。在这些王朝国家中，主权归于王室，但随着民族国家的出现，主权逐渐转移到人民手中。虽然主权的核心在于谁拥有最高政治权威，而非实际的政治权力，但在现实世界中，权威与权力往往紧密相连。在那些新兴国家中，谁掌握最终权力至关重要，因为这些人可能拥有巨大的权力，这意味着他们将对在其统治下的人民产生巨大的影响。

The concept of sovereignty was conceived just as dynastic states were emerging in Europe, which is why they are sometimes referred to as sovereign states. Sovereignty was vested in the crown in those dynastic states, but with the coming of the nation-state, it became lodged in the people. Although sovereignty is all about who has supreme political authority, not actual political power, in the real world authority and power are closely linked. Who possessed ultimate authority mattered greatly in the emerging states, because those people could become remarkably powerful, which meant they would have a huge influence on the people who fell under their purview.

在王朝国家出现之前，欧洲的政治权威和政治权力都更加分散。主权归属往往难以界定。政治社会学家威廉·休厄尔写道，在中世纪（大约公元500年至1500年），“社会该系统既是社团性的，又是等级性的……人们隶属于一系列既定的团结单位，以一种同时协商的方式与其他重叠的群体共享认可的共同体。” 54天主教会拥有一定的权威，但国王、地方贵族、城镇、城市，甚至行会也拥有权威。正如罗伯特·杰克逊所言，政治权威是“多元的、分散的、不连贯的。” 55由于欧洲没有任何一个政治实体比其他竞争对手强大得多，因此确定谁拥有最高权威变得更加困难。

Before the dynastic state came on the scene, both political authority and political power in Europe were much more decentralized. It was often difficult to tell where sovereignty resided. During the Middle Ages (roughly 500 to 1500 AD), writes the political sociologist William Sewell, “The social system was both corporate and hierarchical. . . . People belonged to a whole range of constituted solidarity units, sharing communities of recognition in a simultaneously negotiated fashion with overlapping collections of other persons.”54 The Catholic Church had some authority, but so did kings, the local nobility, towns, cities, and even guilds. Political authority was, as Robert Jackson puts it, “diverse, dislocated, and disjointed.”55 The difficulty of determining who had supreme authority was abetted by the fact that no political entity in Europe was significantly more powerful than its competitors.

人们或许会认为中世纪的国王拥有巨大的政治权力。但实际上，最有权势的政治人物通常是当地的贵族和掌管地方教会的主教。中央政权通常无法与这些地方势力抗衡，后者对个人日常生活的影响力远胜于君主。正如历史学家约瑟夫·斯特雷耶和达纳·芒罗所指出的，“国王既不特别尊贵，也不特别重要。在欧洲的大部分地区，他们并未获得民众的首要效忠，也无法决定国家的政治命运……个人与其君主之间的情感纽带远比对国家那种模糊的效忠观念更为牢固。” 56

One might think that medieval kings had significant political power. But the most powerful political actors were usually the resident nobles and the bishops who ran the local churches. Central authorities were generally no match for these local forces, which had much more influence on an individual’s daily life than did monarchs. As the historians Joseph Strayer and Dana Munro note, “Kings were neither especially dignified nor especially important. In most regions of Europe they did not receive the primary allegiance of their peoples and could not determine the political destinies of their countries. . . . The personal bond between a man and his lord was far stronger than the vague idea of allegiance to the state.”56

16世纪初，随着王朝国家的兴起，局势开始发生变化。王朝国家致力于对其境内所有人民实施政治控制，这意味着罗马天主教会以及地方当局的权威将被削弱。然而，王朝国家需要时间才能在其境内实现权力集中，因为当时的科技水平不足以让王室轻易地投射权力。欧洲的道路系统十分原始，通讯速度也只能依靠马匹或船只，文件复制技术也才刚刚起步。直到欧洲第一批国家出现约三百年后，谈论权力集中于其中心才变得有意义。

The situation began to change in the early 1500s with the emergence of the dynastic state, which was committed to asserting political control over all people within its borders. This meant weakening the authority of the Catholic Church in Rome as well as that of local authorities. Nevertheless, it took time for the dynastic state to centralize control within its borders, because the technology of the day did not permit easy projection of power by the crown. Road systems across Europe were primitive, communication could travel no faster than a horse or a ship, and the capacity to make multiple copies of documents was just beginning to develop.57 Not until some three hundred years after the first states began appearing in Europe did it make sense to talk about concentrated power at their centers.

然而，到了18世纪末，国家已经更有能力对抗境内的地方政权。不出所料，新兴国家对此发展高度关注。它们都渴望建立自己的民族国家。

By the late 1700s, however, the state was much better positioned to confront the local authorities inside its borders. Not surprisingly, the newly emerging nations paid this development much attention. Each wanted its own nation-state.

国家渴望拥有主权有两个原因，第一个原因是自决。像任何大型社会群体一样，国家更倾向于自主管理自己的事务。尽可能地掌握自身命运。实现这一目标的最佳途径是让一个国家掌控塑造其日常生活的政治机构。在现代社会，这意味着拥有自己的国家。当然，并非每个国家都能实现这一目标，而无法实现的国家也并非注定消亡。正如政治哲学家雅艾尔·塔米尔所指出的，“自决权可以通过多种方式实现：文化自治、区域自治、联邦制和邦联制。”但她也承认，“毫无疑问，民族国家能够确保最大程度的民族自治，并为享受民族生活提供最大的可能性。” 58各国自下而上地推动建立能够主导和管理的国家。

Nations covet a state for two reasons, the first of which is self-determination. Like any large social group, nations prefer to run their own affairs and determine their own fates as much as possible. The best way to achieve those ends is for a nation to control the political institutions that shape its daily life. In the modern world, that translates into having one’s own state. Of course, not every nation can fulfill this ambition, and nations that cannot are not necessarily doomed to disappear. As the political philosopher Yael Tamir notes, “The right to self-determination can be realized in a variety of different ways: cultural autonomies, regional autonomies, federations, and confederations.” But she acknowledges that “unquestionably a nation-state can ensure the widest possible degree of national autonomy and the maximum range of possibilities for the enjoyment of national life.”58 Nations push from the bottom up to establish states they can dominate and run.

各国也渴望拥有自己的国家，因为这是最大限度提高自身生存前景的最佳途径。各国面临着各种各样的生存威胁，首先便是现代国家的干预性。王朝国家很少干预境内人民的日常生活。它主要负责征税，并招募数量相对较少的青年男子服兵役。除此之外，人民基本上不受外界干扰，他们的生活由地方文化和政治机构主导。但随着国家对公民生活的介入日益加深，这种情况发生了剧变。国家有强烈的动机将人民塑造成拥有共同语言和共同历史的单一文化。59

Nations also want their own states because this is the best way to maximize their survival prospects. Nations face a variety of threats to their existence, starting with the intrusive nature of the modern state. The dynastic state did not interfere much in the daily lives of the people within its borders. It mainly collected taxes and looked for relatively small numbers of young men who might serve in the army. Otherwise, people were pretty much left alone under the purview of local cultural and political institutions. But as the state became more deeply involved in its citizens’ lives, that changed drastically. States had a powerful incentive to mold their people into a single culture with a common language and a shared history.59

这种文化同质化的冲动，与民族构建密不可分，对多民族国家中的任何少数群体都构成严重威胁，因为多数群体很可能会确保正在形成的共同文化由其自身的语言和传统所定义。少数群体文化很可能被边缘化，甚至消失。正如沃克·康纳所指出的，那些致力于民族构建的国家，往往也同时在进行民族分裂。 60一个国家避免这种命运的最佳途径是拥有自己的国家。这一逻辑解释了为什么在过去的两个世纪里，如此多的多民族国家分崩离析。 61

This impulse to homogenize the culture, which is synonymous with nation-building, presents a grave danger for any minority group in a multinational state, simply because the majority is likely to ensure that the emerging common culture is defined by its own language and traditions. Minority cultures are likely to be pushed aside and maybe even disappear. As Walker Connor points out, states that engage in nation-building are invariably in the business of nation-breaking as well.60 The best way for a nation to avoid that fate is to have its own state. This logic explains why so many multinational states have broken apart over the past two centuries.61

少数族裔国家成员担忧自身生存的另一个原因是他们可能在内战中丧生。1994年卢旺达胡图族对图西族的种族灭绝就是一个很好的例子。这是一场针对图西族的血腥屠杀。少数族裔群体的出现可能出于多种原因。这可能是由于少数族裔在经济中拥有不成比例的影响力而引发的不满，也可能是因为他们被视为第五纵队，就像第一次世界大战期间土耳其境内的亚美尼亚人一样。62拥有自己的国家总是比在一个纷争不断的多民族国家中处于权力平衡的劣势要安全得多。

Another reason members of minority nations worry about their survival is that they might be killed in a civil war. A good example is the Hutu genocide against the Tutsis in Rwanda in 1994. A murderous campaign against a minority group might happen for a number of reasons. It might be driven by resentment over the minority’s disproportionate influence in the economy, or the minority might be seen as a fifth column, like the Armenians in Turkey during World War I.62 It is always safer to have your own state than to be on the short end of the power balance in a fractious multinational state.

最后，在帝国主义时代，民族生存是被征服民族最为关注的问题，而对征服的恐惧在现代国家体系向欧洲以外地区的传播中发挥了重要作用。63从十六世纪初到二十世纪初，欧洲列强建立了横跨全球大片区域的帝国。沦为这些遥远帝国臣民的土著居民，其文化往往遭到帝国主义列强的严重破坏。这些列强经常限制土著居民的教育，摧毁他们的经济，强征他们的青年男子，没收他们的农田，甚至强迫他们沦为名义上的（或实际的）奴隶。在精英阶层的推动下，当地居民最终开始将自身视为民族，并思考自决问题。在大多数情况下，实现这一目标的唯一途径就是脱离帝国，建立独立的民族国家。

Finally, national survival was a matter of great concern for subject peoples during the age of imperialism, and fear of conquest played an important role in spreading the modern state system beyond Europe.63 Between the early sixteenth century and the early twentieth, the European great powers created empires covering large portions of the globe. The indigenous people who became subjects of those far-flung empires often saw their cultures badly damaged by the imperial powers, which frequently restricted the natives’ education, destroyed their economies, conscripted their young men, confiscated their farmland, and even forced native peoples into virtual (or actual) slavery. Local populations, spurred on by their elites, eventually began to see themselves as nations and to think about self-determination. In most cases, the only way to achieve that end was to break away from the empire and establish an independent nation-state.

这些促使一个民族渴望建立自己国家的充分理由，极大地促进了民族国家的发展。反之亦然：王朝国家也有充分的理由转变为民族国家，因为当人民组织成民族时，国家本身也会从中受益匪浅。

These persuasive reasons for a nation to want its own state have contributed greatly to the development of the nation-state. The converse is true as well: dynastic states had compelling reasons to turn themselves into nation-states, as states benefit greatly when their people are organized into nations.

国家为何需要民族国家

Why States Want Nations

民族主义对于经济和军事上的成功都至关重要，而经济和军事上的成功对一个国家的生存都起着举足轻重的作用。统治精英们也通过努力使民众服从统治来促进民族主义——这绝非易事。

Nationalism is essential for economic as well as military success, both of which matter greatly for a state’s survival. Governing elites also foster nationalism through their efforts to make their populations governable—never an easy task.

在工业时代，想要在经济上竞争的国家别无选择，只能创造共同的文化，正如欧内斯特·盖尔纳在其经典著作《民族与民族主义》中所论述的那样。工业需要识字且能够相互交流的劳动者。这意味着国家需要普及教育以及共同的语言。工业社会，换言之，语言需要高度的文化同质性；它们需要一个民族。国家在培育这种共同文化方面发挥着主导作用，尤其是在教育领域，国家在决定课堂教学内容方面扮演着核心角色。“合法教育的垄断，”盖尔纳写道，“如今比合法暴力的垄断更为重要，更为核心。” 64

In the industrial age, states that want to compete economically have no choice but to create a common culture, as Ernest Gellner argues in his classic work Nations and Nationalism. Industry requires laborers who are literate and can communicate with each other. This means states need universal education as well as a common language. Industrial societies, in other words, demand a high degree of cultural homogeneity; they require a nation. The state plays the leading role in fostering that shared culture, especially through education, where it plays a central role in determining what is taught in the classroom. “The monopoly of legitimate education,” Gellner writes, “is now more important, more central than is the monopoly of legitimate violence.”64

各国出于维护国家安全的考虑，也有充分的理由去推广民族主义。正如巴里·波森所指出的，“任何能够论证识字和共同文化在经济上的作用的论点，至少同样适用于其在军事上的作用，尤其是在大规模战争中。” 66大量证据表明，受过教育的士兵在战斗中的表现远胜于文盲士兵。而且，与那些语言和文化背景不同的士兵相比，讲同一种语言、拥有许多相同习俗和信仰的士兵更容易被训练成一支高效的战斗力量。 67

There are also compelling national security reasons for states to promote nationalism.65 As Barry Posen notes, “Any argument that one can make for the economic function of literacy and a shared culture is at least as plausible for a military function, particularly in mass warfare.”66 There is an abundance of evidence showing that educated soldiers perform far better in combat than illiterate ones. And compared with those with different languages and cultures, soldiers who speak the same language and share many of the same practices and beliefs are more easily molded into an effective fighting force.67

民族主义还有另一种强大的倍增作用。由于民族主义能够将人民与其国家紧密联系在一起，战时领导人——尤其是在极端紧急时期——通常能够动员民众坚定地支持战争，穿上军装参战。民族国家能够组建庞大的军队并长期维持下去。例如，第一次世界大战中没有哪个列强出现兵力短缺的情况。在那场惨烈无比的战争中，各国政府每年都会定期补充大量符合条件的男性新兵，以填补数以万计的阵亡士兵。（最终，战争造成约900万军人和700万平民丧生。）但这并不意味着军队在经历了多年的残酷战斗后永远不会崩溃，就像1917年秋季的俄军和一年后的德军一样。1917年春季，法军也发生了兵变。此外，这也不否认公众对一个民族国家战争的支持可能会迅速消散。

There is another way in which nationalism is a huge force multiplier. Because nationalism creates tight bonds between a people and their state, leaders in wartime—especially in times of extreme emergency—can usually get their citizens to steadfastly support the war effort and put on a uniform and fight.68 Nation-states can raise large militaries and sustain them for long periods of time. None of the great powers in World War I, for example, ran out of soldiers. During each year of that unbelievably bloody conflict, the governments routinely replaced their many thousands of lost soldiers with a new crop of eligible males. (In the end, the war killed about nine million in uniform and seven million civilians.) This does not mean armies never collapse after years of deadly fighting, as the Russian army did in the fall of 1917 and the German army did a year later. The French army mutinied in the spring of 1917. Nor is it to deny that public support for a nation-state’s war may quickly evaporate.

然而，民族主义的作用远不止于扩大一个国家的军事力量。它还能使士兵、水手和飞行员更加忠诚，更加忠于祖国。在王朝统治时期，逃兵是军事指挥官在战前和战时面临的一大难题。统治者从本国社会中招募雇佣兵和“罪犯、流浪汉和穷人”来组建军队，而这些人士兵们对他们为之战斗的国家几乎没有忠诚感。69远比起忠诚，他们更强烈的动机是避免战死。当士兵来自民族主义情绪高涨的群体时，逃兵问题就少得多：他们随时准备挺身而出，保卫祖国。拿破仑敏锐地捕捉到了这种转变，他宣称：“凡是把生命看得比国家荣耀和战友的尊重更重要的人，都不应该成为法国军队的一员。” 70

Nationalism, however, does more than increase the size of a country’s military forces. It also makes soldiers, sailors, and airmen more reliable and committed to fighting for their country.
